conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to follow these steps.
The magnetic flux Î¦ through the coil is given by Î¦ = B â‹… A â‹… cos(Î¸).
B is the magnetic field strength, A is the area of the coil, Î¸ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil's surface.
Since the coil is rotating with angular velocity Ï‰, the angle Î¸ changes with time t as Î¸ = Ï‰t.
The area A of the square coil is A = LÂ².
Substituting the area and the angle into the flux equation: Î¦(t) = B â‹… LÂ² â‹… cos(Ï‰t).
The induced EMF ğ“” is given by Faraday's Law of Induction: ğ“” = -N dÎ¦/dt.
Differentiating Î¦(t) with respect to time: dÎ¦/dt = -B â‹… LÂ² â‹… Ï‰ â‹… sin(Ï‰t).
The induced EMF is: ğ“”(t) = N â‹… B â‹… LÂ² â‹… Ï‰ â‹… sin(Ï‰t).
The effective value (RMS) of the EMF for a sinusoidal waveform is given by: ğ“”_rms = ğ“”_max/âˆš2.
The maximum EMF ğ“”_max is: ğ“”_max = N â‹… B â‹… LÂ² â‹… Ï‰.
The effective value of the EMF is: ğ“”_rms = (N â‹… B â‹… LÂ² â‹… Ï‰)/âˆš2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is: ğ“”_rms = (N â‹… B â‹… LÂ² â‹… Ï‰)/âˆš2.
